description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco has decided that all contact subjects of confirmed cases of COVID-19 will be able to take biological tests. Is considered a contact subject: any person who has touched or who has remained within 2 meters for more than 15 minutes of the person suffering from COVID-19; anyone who has spoken with the COVID-19 patient; anyone who has cleaned the body fluids of the COVID-19 patient without protection; the group of close friends; anyone living in the same home or attending the same dormitory as the COVID-19 patient.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description: Monaco government to launch mass Covid-10 testing campaign, offering free voluntary rapid tests to all residents over the age of 5, starting May 18th. Tests to be available to residents 5 years and under starting June 3. UPDATE: Free serological testing for Monaco residents to expand to children under 5 years starting June 3.
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From May 19, 2020, Monaco begins its COVID-19 serological testingcampaign among its entire population. The choice of organization fell on the alphabetical order of families for all residents aged 5 and over. All costs inherent in the tests and any blood tests will be borne by the State. The result will be communicate directly within 10 minutes. An official letter will be sent to each household to explain the process and its implementation. The testing centers will be open every day except Sunday and will accommodate up to 4,000 residents per day. The alphabetical order of passage will be communicated through the press, posters and on social networks. Members of the same family, one of whose parents has the usual name beginning with the referring letter, can go at the same time with the spouse and children. In the event of unavailability during the designated time slot, remedial sessions will be organized.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Health testing of entire population under the government's jurisdiction
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective May 19 and until further notice, Monaco decided that if the result of a serological test (TROD) is positive, the positive person will be invited to take a blood test in a laboratory (at the expense of the State), to determine more precisely his viral load and when he crossed the line. The result will be commnicate within 1 or 2 days. If this period is less than 7 days, the time of active contamination, a nasopharyngeal PCR test will determine whether the person is affected by the virus, which will result in his mandatory quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Confirmed contact to a person infected with COVID-19

description: From June 2, Monaco begins its COVID-19 serological testing campaign among its residents under the age of 5. This campaign was previously only targeted people of 5 years old and above. Screening can be done from 1:30 p.m. to 6 p.m., on the Grimaldi Forum Monaco site. The result will be communicate directly within 10 minutes. The tests are free of charge.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: From June 2, Monaco is starting its serological testing campaign for all people working in the Principality (employees, civil servants and state agents and self-employed workers who are not necessarily residents of the Principality). The tests, free of charge, are taking place between 7:30 a.m. and 6 p.m. on the Grimaldi Forum site alone. Testing is voluntary and confidential. The organization of the reception of people is done on the basis of alphabetical order.

description: Effective April 24 and until May 31, Monaco decided that the storage of waste from healthcare activities with infectious and similar risks is subject to the following provisions. (1) The time between the production of this waste and its removal from the place of its production does not exceed: a) five days when the quantity of this waste produced on the same site is greater than 100 kilograms per week; b) ten days when the quantity of this waste produced on the same site is less than or equal to 100 kilograms per week and greater than 15 kilograms per month; c) one month, regardless of the quantities produced, for waste from personal protective equipment used by nursing staff. (2) The time between the evacuation of this waste and its incineration or pretreatment by disinfection does not exceed 20 days when the quantity of this waste grouped together in the same place is greater than or equal to 15 kilograms per month. If it is not possible to incinerate or pre-treat within this period, this waste may be stored for a period not exceeding 3 months.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Effective April 24 and until May 31, Monaco decided that the time between the production of waste from healthcare activities with infectious and similar perforating risks and their incineration or pretreatment by disinfection does not exceed 6 months when the quantity of this waste produced on the same site is less than or equal to 15 kilograms per months and more than 5 kilograms per month. The time between the production of this waste and its removal does not exceed 6 months when the quantity of this waste produced in the same place is less than or equal to 5 kilograms per month. The removal of this waste from the place of production and its incineration or pretreatment by disinfection does not exceed 6 months when the quantity of this waste grouped together in the same place is less than or equal to 15 kilograms per month.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Monaco is enforcing a lockdown from March 18 to March 31. The movement of any person outside their home is prohibited, with the exception of trips for the following reasons: (1) trips between the home and the place(s) of exercise of professional activity, when they are essential for carrying out activities that cannot be organized in the form of teleworking or constitute business trips that cannot be postponed; (2) travel to purchase supplies necessary for professional activity and essential purchases in local establishments and businesses authorized to welcome the public; (3) travel for health reasons; (4) travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable persons or for the care of children; (5) short trips, close to home, linked to the individual physical activity of people, to the exclusion of any collective sporting activity, and to the needs of pets. The police will carry out checks. Regarding the exception related to business travel, a certificate of necessity must be completed by the employer.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Since March 18, Monaco is under lockdown. On March 27, Monaco changed the conditions why people can be outside and extended the initial length of the lockdown's policy. Reasons why people can be outside, from March 27 to April 15: (1) travel between home and place(s) of exercise of professional activity, when they are essential for the exercise of activities that cannot be organized in the form of telework or constitute professional trips that cannot be deferred; (2) travel to purchase supplies necessary for professional activity and essential purchases in local establishments and businesses authorized to welcome the public; (3) travel for health reasons, namely consultations and care that cannot be provided remotely and cannot be postponed; (4) consultations and care of patients with long-term illness; (5) travel for family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable persons or childcare; (6) short trips, linked either to the individual physical activity, to a walk with only people grouped together in the same home, to the needs of pets; (7) travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons; (8) travel for participation in missions of general interest at the request of the administrative authority. Regarding the exception related to business travel, a certificate of necessity must be completed by the employer. The Public Security will ensure the strict application of these provisions. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Since March 18, Monaco was under a lockdown and forbade people from going to their boats in Monaco's ports. Effective May 4 and until further notice, pleasure boating from Monaco's ports is authorized in the same day from 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. This measure applies to all vessels, whatever their flag, having in the Principality, at the time of their departure, a berth annually or in transit. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco is no longer under lockdown. However, the governement recommends to continue to restrict travel to the maximum extent possible, in particular for vulnerable persons.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since March 18, Monaco was under a lockdown and forbade people from going to their boats in Monaco's ports. Effective May 4 and until further notice, pleasure boating from Monaco's ports is authorized in the same day from 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. This measure applies to all vessels, whatever their flag, having in the Principality, at the time of their departure, a berth annually or in transit. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. UPDATE: Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco decided to increse the fine. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 3, Monaco decided, via the Department of Interior, the following measures related to end-of-year exams in National Education: (1) The 2020 bac will take place without written exams and will be awarded only on the basis of continuous assessment (grades obtained during the confinement period will not be taken into account); (2) For 1st year classes, only the oral French is maintained (the test could be held at the end of June or the beginning of July if sanitary conditions allow it); (3) an examination board will study the school booklets in order to look at "the case of each student" and "guarantee harmonization between the candidates" (it will take into account the attendance of the students at the time of a possible resumption of the course and until July 4, as well as its progress); (4) the endorsements are maintained; (5) the principle of the oral catch-up is maintained in July (subject to feasibility); (6) candidates who do not obtain the baccalaureate in July (overall score below 8/20) may retake it in September on the advice of the jury (criterion of attendance and motivation); (7) the BEP, CAP, Bac pro, BTS tests are validated on the basis of the marks obtained during the year and the exams already taken during this school year.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_text: what will be taken in consideration for final results in school
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided to authorize the practice of individual physical and sporting activities indoors or outdoors, subject to compliance with health measures: (1) health distancing and maintenance of barrier gestures; (2) the use of changing rooms is prohibited; (3) provide a contactless space between two people beyond 1.50 m (10 m for cycling and running; 5 m for fast walking; 1.5 m sideways between two people; for other activities, provide a space of 4 m² for each participant); (4) snacks and hydration are managed individually; (5) the exchange or sharing of personal effects is prohibited; (6) the use of personal equipment is privileged, failing which, common equipment is cleaned and disinfected before and after each use; (7) gatherings organized on public roads or in private places are limited to a group of no more than 5 people. The practice of physical and sports activities in groups or in contact remains prohibited. Any failure to comply with this decision will be punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros. A second verbalization is punished with a fine of 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days, the fine is 1,000 to 2,250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since June 2, Monaco authorizes the practice of individual physical and sporting activities indoors or outdoors. Effective June 4 and until further notice, the praticte of this activity is subject to compliance with these measures: (1) practice a sporting activity while respecting the rules of sanitary distancing and maintaining barrier gestures; (2) in the case of collective changing rooms, the number of people able to access them will be limited to one person for 4 m²; (3) provide a contactless space between two people beyond 1.50 m (10 m for cycling and running; 5 m for brisk walking (side by side or in front / behind) ; 1.5 m laterally between two people; provide a space of 4 m² for each participant for other activities); (4) individually manage snacks and hydration; (5) prohibit the exchange or sharing of personal effects; (6) favor the use of personal equipment, failing which, common equipment is cleaned and disinfected before and after each use. Any failure to comply with this decision will be punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros. A second verbalization is punished with a fine of 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days, the fine is 1,000 to 2,250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: conditions for the practice of individual physical and sporting activities indoors or outdoors
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Presented in a very graphic way, they describe a chain of questions and actions to do in certain situations. description: On January 30, Monaco published, on social medias, a reflex sheet intended to the public to explain what a person suspected to have the coronavirus has to do. Only people exposed for less than 14 days, having stayed in China or having been in close contact with a person infected with the virus and presenting a lower respiratory infection (cough and fever) are considered as suspect. These people should avoid contact, call the fire brigade, wash theirs hands frequently and wear a mask.

description: On February 24, Monaco published a reflex sheet intended to the public to explain what a person suspected to have the coronavirus should do. Those who have stayed or transited in China (including Hong-Kong and Macau), Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia or Italy (only Lombardy and Veneto) should take their temperature twice a day and, if they have the symptoms of COVID-19, call the fire department, wash your hands frequently and wear a mask.

description: On Febryary 28, via a document intented to the public and published online, Monaco recommended to its residents to follow these measure in order to prevent the spread of COVID-19: Washing hands often with soap water for at least 20 seconds or with a hydro-alcoholic solution; disinfect hands when leaving and returning home; disinfect hands when arriving or leaving the workplace; disinfect hands before eating food; disinfect hands before and after sports activities; disinfect hands when taking and leaving public transport; cough or blow your nose into a disposable tissue which is immediately put in the trash; not going to an educational institution if you are not feeling well; never touch your eyes, nose or mouth with unwashed or disinfected hands; avoid approaching sick people; periodically clean and decontaminate surfaces; wear a surgical mask when going to the doctor if you have symptoms. Monaco affirmed that there are no special precautions to be taken for contact persons while awaiting the test results of the COVID-19. These informations were repeated on social medias and in press conferences.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective February 24 and until further notice, anyone arriving or present in the national territory and presenting a risk or signs of potential infection by the Covid-19 is quarantined during the incubation period of the virus and the performance of the necessary examinations. The Director of Health Action specifies the initial duration of the placement, which cannot exceed fourteen days. He also has the possibility of renewing or lifting the measure before the planned term, in view of the state of health of the person concerned, of the cases which could have been declared and of the evolution of scientific knowledge on COVID-19.

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, anyone who went to an area considered at risk by the Director of Health Action must make himself known to this directorate and be subject to a quarantine measure (even if they are asymptomatic) if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong-Kong and Macao), Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Iran, Barhein and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. The maximum period during which each insured subject to a measure of eviction from the workplace or quarantine may benefit from the daily allowances paid under these conditions is set at 14 days.

description: Since January 30, those who have been exposed for less than 14 days, have been in an area considered at risk or have been in close contact with a person infected with the COVID-19 and presenting a lower respiratory infection (cough and fever) are considered suspect. People who think they are infected should not go to their doctor or hospital, but stay at home. Effective February 24 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong-Kong and Macau), Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia and Italy (only in Lombardy or Veneto). UPDATE: The policy ends on February 27 because of a change in geographic target and in the condition for which one has to be in quarantine.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all contact subjects of confirmed cases of COVID-19 will be confined to their homes for 14 days. The following people are considered to be a contact subject: any person who has touched or who has remained within 2 meters for more than 15 minutes from the person suffering from COVID-19; anyone who has spoken with the COVID-19 patient; anyone who has cleaned the body fluids of the COVID-19 patient without protection; the group of close friends; anyone living in the same home or attending the same dormitory as the COVID-19 patient.

description: Regardless of nationality, anyone who wishes to enter the Principality from either:    -A country outside Europe  -A country within Europe which has recorded more than 60 cases per 100,000 people in 14 days must contact the COVID-19 Call Centre as soon as they arrive in Monaco.    They will be subject to a quarantine imposed by the Director of Health Affairs. Quarantine can be waived if the person entering the country provides proof of a negative PCR test or, for those who are asymptomatic, proof of a negative antigen test conducted no more than 72 hours before their arrival, in their country of origin. The quarantine period can be cut short if the person undergoes a PCR test carried out by a medical biology laboratory (Laboratory in the Principality of Monaco or a laboratory. Alternatively, those who are asymptomatic can undergo an antigen test on arrival (carried out by a chemist, doctor or nurse), if negative, this will also cut short the quarantine period. If the antigen test is positive, the individual will need to undergo a PCR test in one of the laboratories referred to above. In the event of a positive PCR test or a refusal to undergo a test, quarantine measures will remain in place.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: Regardless of nationality, anyone aged 16 or over, who wishes to enter the Principality must be able to present all the documents required for their zone of origin (green zone, orange zone, red zone) on arrival. Travelers from an orange zone country must present evidence of full vaccination or recovery from Covid-19 (if neither requirement can be fulfilled, travelers must provide evidence that travel is for an essential reason, present a negative PCR test, and self-isolate for 7 days upon arrival).

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they are asymptomatic. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund returning from risk areas defined by the Director of Health Action must make themselves known to this Department and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for a period of fourteen days after returning from a risk area if the employee is not subject to a work stoppage.

description: Since February 27, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they are asymptomatic. Effective March 2 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau) Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna), France (Oise (only this department in Hauts-de-France)). Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Temperature Check,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: Oise Department (Hauts-de-France)
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Since February 27, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund returning from risk areas defined by the Director of Health Action must make themselves known to this Department and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. Effective March 2 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau) Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna), France (Oise (only this department in Hauts-de-France)). A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for a period of fourteen days after returning from a risk area if the employee is not subject to a work stoppage.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they are asymptomatic. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading. UPDATE: The policy ends on March 2 because of a change in the areas considered at risk.

If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.

description: Since February 27, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund returning from risk areas defined by the Director of Health Action must make themselves known to this Department and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. Effective March 8 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong, Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, Asti (only this province of Piedmont)), France (Oise (only this Department of Hauts-de-France), Bourgogne Franche Comté, Grand Est, La Balme-de-Sillingy (only this commune of Auvergne-Rhone-Alpes)), Germany (Würtemberg (only this part of Bade-Wurtemberg), Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid), Netherlands, United States (King County (only this county in Washington State)), Iran, Bahrain and Vietnam. A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for a period of fourteen days after returning from a risk area if the employee is not subject to a work stoppage. UPDATE: The policy ends on March 11 because of a change in the areas considered at risk.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Since February 27, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund returning from risk areas must make themselves known to the Director of Health Action. They are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to Monegasques, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy and to security of State. Effective March 11 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, Piedmont (only in Alessandria, Asti and Turin)), France (Aude and Calvados departments and these municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Wurtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for 14 days after returning from a risk area if he is not subject to a work stoppage. Food stores and markets, pharmacies, tobacconists and newsagents, gas stations and banks will remain open. All other commercial establishments (including restaurants, casinos, cafes, theaters, cinemas and nightclubs) have to apply this measure.

description: Effective March 16 and until further notice, Monaco decided that employees affiliated with the Social Services Compensation Fund, parents of a child under 16 (or 18 in the event of a disability) whose school or kindergarden is temporarily closed in order to limit the spread of Covid-19, must assess with their employer the possibility of implementing a remote working mode for the duration of the closure of the school or kindergarden. The employer's refusal to set up remote work must be justified. If they cannot benefit from an adjustment of their working conditions allowing them to stay at home to look after their child, the insured can benefit from a work stoppage compensated by the Monegasque health insurance fund to which they are. members, on condition that the other parent is not placed in a situation of temporary total unemployment.

description: Effective March 17 and until further notice, food stores have to respect some restrictions: There should not be more than one person per 12 square meters; entry into the store must be regulated by markings to keep a distance of 1.5 meters in each person; in cases where the queue to enter the store is more than 50 people, the establishment must provide customers with tickets with a transit time; when the store opens, there must be a 1 hour window for people aged 70 and over; hydroalcoholic solutions must be made available to the staff of the cash registers.

description: From March 18, Monaco decided that to maintain activity on a construction site, the project owners will have to confirm that they are able to enforce the measures precaunized by the government. Effective March 18 and until March 31, theses measures are: to wash hands very regularly either with soap and water for at least twenty seconds or, in the absence of water and soap, with a hydro-alcoholic product, rubbing until the skin is dry; to greet without shaking hands and hugging; to keep a minimum distance of at least one meter from any other person; to cough or sneeze into our elbow or into a disposable tissue; to use disposable handkerchiefs.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Since March 14, places open to the public that are not essential to the life of the country must stay close to the public. Effective March 18 and until April 15, Monaco brought precisions regarding that policy. The following buisenesses must close to the public whitout condition: halls for shows, auditions, conferences, meetings; dance halls and games rooms; holiday centers, leisure centers without accommodation; exhibition halls; covered sports establishments; marquees, tents and itinerant structures or with prolonged or fixed installation; outdoor establishments.

description: Since March 14, places open to the public that are not essential to the life of the country must stay close to the public. Food stores and markets, pharmacies, tobacconists and newsagents, gas stations and banks were allowed to stay open. Effective March 18 and until April 15, Monaco precised that stores carrying out one of the following activities are authorized to welcome the public: Maintenance and repair of vehicles; sale of automotive equipment; necessary supplies for farms; food trade; multi-store stores; food distributions provided by charitable associations; public food markets, sale of fuel; sale of information and communication equipment; sale of computers, peripheral units and software; sale of telecommunications equipment; sale of building materials; sale of newspapers and stationery; sale of pharmaceutical products; sale of medical and orthopedic articles; sale of optical goods; sale of pet food and supplies; Hotels and similar accommodation; rental of machinery, equipment and goods; activities of labor placement agencies; activities of temporary employment agencies; repair of computers and personal and household goods; repair of communication equipment; laundry-dyeing; funeral services; financial and insurance activities.

On March 18 and until April 15, Monaco precised that restaurants and drinking establishments must close their doors to the public, except for their delivery and take-away activities, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and collective catering under contract. Stores and shopping centers have also to close their doors to the public, except for their delivery and order pick-up activities.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco recommends to temporarily work remotely. UPDATE: Effective March 18 and until March 31, Monaco decided that employers must, as a first step, assess the possibility of generalizing the use of remote work in their company. If remote work is not compatible with the activity of the company and in order to ensure the continuation of the activity, the employer must give each employee concerned a document establishing the need for the employee to go to work phisically. The same applies when a business trip cannot be postponed. Employees must bring their proof of professional travel when they go to work.

description: Since February 27, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund who work in entities of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they are asymptomatic. Effective March 11 and until further notice, the risk areas are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, Piedmont (only in Alessandria, Asti and Turin), France (Aude and Calvados departments and these municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Würtemberg (only this region of Bade-Wurtemberg), Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). Entities of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential for the life of Monegasques, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy, and to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading. UPDATE: On March 20, the Monegasque government repealed the ministerial decision that established that policy.

description: Since February 27, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund returning from risk areas must make themselves known to the Department of Health Action and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance, which are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the life of the Monegasque population, the exercise of the authority of the State, the functioning of the economy or the security of State. Since March 11, areas at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, and provinces of Alessandria, Asti and Turin in Piedmont), France (Aude and Calvados departments and these municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Würtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). Effective March 13 and until further notice, teleworking can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for all or part of the weekly working time. UPDATE: On March 20, the Monegasque government repealed the ministerial decision that established that policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: From March 18, Monaco decided that to maintain activity on a construction site, the project owners will have to confirm that they are able to enforce the measures precaunized by the government. Effective March 18 and until March 31, theses measures are: to wash hands very regularly either with soap and water for at least twenty seconds or, in the absence of water and soap, with a hydro-alcoholic product, rubbing until the skin is dry; to greet without shaking hands and hugging; to keep a minimum distance of at least one meter from any other person; to cough or sneeze into our elbow or into a disposable tissue; to use disposable handkerchiefs. UPDATE: On March 31, Monaco decided to extend this policy until May 31.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco recommends to temporarily work remotely. UPDATE: Monaco decided that from March 18 and until March 31, employers must, as a first step, assess the possibility of generalizing the use of remote work in their company. If remote work is not compatible with the activity of the company and in order to ensure the continuation of the activity, the employer must give each employee concerned a document establishing the need for the employee to go to work phisically. The same applies when a business trip cannot be postponed. Employees must bring their proof of professional travel when they go to work. On March 27, Monaco decided to extend that policy until April 15.

description: Effective April 10 and until further notice, Monaco decided that before resumption or execution of any construction work begins, a file detailing all the measures envisaged, accompanied by an explanatory plan of the organization of the cantonments (by specifying in particular the changing rooms occupied, the places in the refectory, the traffic flows to avoid crossings, the positioning of the water points, the distances expressed in meters between each occupied changing room, each seat, between the tables themselves, etc.) and the detailed list of all the staff as well as their origin must be submitted to the Department of Foresight, Town Planning and Mobility. This file is submitted by the client, in agreement with the intervening companies. The measures must include: compliance with barrier gestures (minimum distance of one meter, frequent hand washing, wearing of a mask, regular disinfection of site premises, machinery and vehicles); taking the temperature at the entrance to the site; ban on eating outside the work site and eating face-to-face; prohibition of recourse to long journeys, except in cases of imperative necessity; ban on the use of temporary workers; mandatory designation, by the Contracting Authority, of a COVID 19 referent, able to stop the work. Any infringement will be noted by sworn officers and prosecuted in accordance with the law.

description: Since March 14, places open to the public that are not essential to the life of the country must stay close to the public. Food stores and markets, pharmacies, tobacconists and newsagents, gas stations and banks were allowed to stay open. Effective March 18 and until April 15, Monaco precised that stores carrying out one of the following activities are authorized to welcome the public: Maintenance and repair of vehicles; sale of automotive equipment; necessary supplies for farms; food trade; multi-store stores; food distributions provided by charitable associations; public food markets, sale of fuel; sale of information and communication equipment; sale of computers, peripheral units and software; sale of telecommunications equipment; sale of building materials; sale of newspapers and stationery; sale of pharmaceutical products; sale of medical and orthopedic articles; sale of optical goods; sale of pet food and supplies; Hotels and similar accommodation; rental of machinery, equipment and goods; activities of labor placement agencies; activities of temporary employment agencies; repair of computers and personal and household goods; repair of communication equipment; laundry-dyeing; funeral services; financial and insurance activities. UPDATE: This policy is extended until May 3.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective April 24 and until further notice, Monaco decided that for the demolition and/or reconstruction of a building, the elevations and civil engineering works, a file detailing all the measures envisaged, accompanied by an explanatory plan of the organization of the cantonments (specifying in particular the changing rooms occupied, the refectory places, the traffic flows to avoid crossings, the positioning water points, the distances expressed in meters between each changing room occupied, each seating position, between the tables themselves, etc.) and the detailed list of all staff as well as their origin must be submitted to the Department of Prospective, Urbanism and of Mobility. This file is submitted by the client, in agreement with the intervening companies. For work subject to building authorization other than those referred upper as well as for the renovations of buildings, the Department of Prospective, Urban Planning and Mobility must be informed by the COVID-19 referent of the takeover or execution. It is up to him to obtain the prior agreement of the client if the latter is not COVID-19 referent. Any violation of the provisions of this decree and its appendix will be noted by sworn officers and prosecuted in accordance with the law.

description: On May 1, for activities other than those related to construction, the Monegasque Commission for the Control of Nominative Information (CCIN) indicated that the use of a temperature measurement must correspond to a particular requirement and must be done in a proportionate manner. The criteria applicable to the temperature measurement of employees: (1) written procedure specifying the temperature threshold beyond which access to the site is not authorized; (2) communication of this procedure to employee representative bodies and to the labor inspectorate; (3) prior information to employees regarding these conditions; (4) possibility for the employee to refuse to submit to the temperature measurement (the employer can therefore accept the employee at the workplace under the conditions he sets, or send him home without legal or financial consequences); (5) confidentiality applicable to temperature measurement and possibility of refusal; (6) No automated system for taking the temperature of the persons concerned should be deployed before they have been able to consent or refuse the taking of their temperature. With regard to store customers, the CCIN asks not to make access subject to a temperature measurement.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that food stores must follow these measure: (1) mask is mandatory for everyone; (2) provide a dispenser of hydro-alcoholic product at entrances to the store, in the toilets, dressing rooms and changing rooms; (3) mark out an entrance and an exit with signage, in businesses that have at least two entrances or an entrance with sufficient width; (4) materialize with signage, whenever possible, traffic flows; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of customers authorized in the shop, taking as a basis one person for 4 m²; (6) provide a dedicated agent for businesses with an area greater than 700 m² in order to manage the flow; (7) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (8) equip the staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing with soap and disinfection; (9) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip the staff with a visor for operations during collections or all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) as far as possible assign individual work tools; (14) set up a time slot at the opening for people over 65, pregnant women and people with disabilities. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Supermarkets/grocery stores") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all stores and shopping centers can reopen. General measures they have to follow: (1) ensure that customers wear a mask; (2) provide hydro-alcoholic product at entrances, in toilets, dressing rooms, changing rooms; (3) mark out an entrance and an exit with signage, when possible; (4) signage, whenever possible, traffic flows; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of customers authorized (with a basis of one person/4 m²); (6) provide a dedicated agent for businesses with an area greater than 700 m² to manage the flow; (7) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (8) equip the staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing and disinfection; (9) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip the staff with a visor for all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) it possible, assign individual work tools. A distance of 1,5 m between each other is mandatory. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all stores and shopping centers can reopen. General measures they have to follow: (1) ensure that customers wear a mask; (2) provide hydro-alcoholic product at entrances, in toilets, dressing rooms, changing rooms; (3) mark out an entrance and an exit with signage, when possible; (4) signage, whenever possible, traffic flows; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of customers authorized (with a basis of one person/4 m²); (6) provide a dedicated agent for businesses with an area greater than 700 m² to manage the flow; (7) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (8) equip the staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing and disinfection; (9) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip the staff with a visor for all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) it possible, assign individual work tools. A distance of 1,5 m between each other is mandatory. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all shopping centers can reopen. Shopping centers must comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures: (1) provide hydro-alcoholic product at entrances and in the toilets and continuously supply soap dispensers; (2) mark out an entrance and an exit; (3) signage traffic flows; (4) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of authorized customers, taking as a base one for 12 m², staff included (to do this: organize queues at the entrance of the shops with a 1.5 m spacing between customers and set up a system for counting flows at entrances and exits); (5) equip security personnel with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and tweezers in the event that disposable masks are distributed to customers; (6) use video surveillance to detect, treat and remove high density areas; (7) adapt the use of benches to respect a distance of 1.5 m between two seats; (8) increase the disinfection of the areas most often affected; (9) increase the quantity of fresh air injected and perform “free cooling” regularly during opening hours while limiting appliance condensation; (10) Establish and disseminate a protocol for take-out sales and the delivery service of catering outlets; (11) set up a protocol for the security personnel to take charge of a person presenting symptoms.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Hairdressers, beauty salons and nail bars are allowed to reopen their doors to the public. However, these establishments are required to comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. The non-recognition of these measures by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures concerning hairdressing salons, beauty institutes and nail bars: (1) ensure a distance of 1.5 m between workstations; (2) welcome clients only by appointment with sufficient margin to avoid waiting; (3) provide staff and customers with alcohol-based hand rubs at each workstation; (4) systematically change the work instruments between each client and soak the instruments previously used in a disinfectant solution; (5) clean and disinfect objects, surfaces and work equipment that may have been contaminated; (6) change disposable single-use (bathrobe, headband, towel, etc.) or washable linen between each client and placed without delay after use in a dedicated resealable bag; (7) use single-use and disposable razors; (8) provide for the installation of a transparent protective screen or the wearing of a mask and visor; (9) not to offer magazines or digital tablets; (10) not offer food or drink to customers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, fashion and ready-to-wear stores can reopen their doors to the public. However, these establishments are required to comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. The non-recognition of these measures by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures concerning fashion and ready-to-wear stores: (1) plan to use only one fitting room in two; (2) when trying on clothes to put on over the head (dress, t-shirt, etc.), it is necessary to (a) provide the customer with a square of fabric large enough to cover the entire face, which must be thrown or changed between each customer, placed in a resealable bag and washed at 60 ° C, and (b) to proceed with a high temperature steam anti-crease on the clothes after they have been tried on and for any item returned for exchange.

description: Effective March 17 and until further notice, food stores have to respect some restrictions: There should not be more than one person per 12 square meters; entry into the store must be regulated by markings to keep a distance of 1.5 meters in each person; in cases where the queue to enter the store is more than 50 people, the establishment must provide customers with tickets with a transit time; when the store opens, there must be a 1 hour window for people aged 70 and over; hydroalcoholic solutions must be made available to the staff of the cash registers. UPDATE: This policy ends on May 4 because Monaco changed who must benefit from the reserved time credit.

description: Since March 14, places open to the public that are not essential to the life of the country must stay close to the public. Effective March 18 and until April 15, Monaco brought precisions regarding that policy. The following buisenesses must close to the public whitout condition: halls for shows, auditions, conferences, meetings; dance halls and games rooms; holiday centers, leisure centers without accommodation; exhibition halls; covered sports establishments; marquees, tents and itinerant structures or with prolonged or fixed installation; outdoor establishments. UPDATE: This policy was first extended until May 3. Effective May 4, it is extended until further notice.

description: Since March 14, places open to the public that are not essential to the life of the country must stay close to the public. On March 18 and until April 15, Monaco precised that restaurants and drinking establishments must close their doors to the public, except for their delivery and take-away activities, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and collective catering under contract. Stores and shopping centers have also to close their doors to the public, except for their delivery and order pick-up activities. UPDATE: This policy was first extended until May 3. Effective May 4, it is extended until further notice.

description: Since May 4, Monaco has decided that food stores must follow these measures: (1) hydro-alcoholic product at the entrances and in the toilets; (2) mark an entrance and an exit with signage, when possible; (3) materialize traffic flows with signage when possible; (4) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of authorized customers, on the basis of one person per 4 m²; (5) provide a dedicated agent to manage the flows of companies with an area greater than 700 m²; (6) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (7) staff have sufficient masks and hand rubs and wash their hands frequently; (8) install a transparent protective screen or, if not possible, equip staff with a visor for all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) where possible, assign individual work tools; (14) set up a time slot at the opening for people over 65, pregnant women and people with disabilities. As of May 14 and until further notice, Monaco has clarified the obligation regarding masks: all those aged 5 years and over must wear a mask inside and in the queues at the outside. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

A distance of 1,5 m between each other is mandatory. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure. Effective May 14 and until further notice, children under 5 do not have to wear maks. description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that food stores must follow these measure: (1) mask is mandatory for everyone; (2) provide a dispenser of hydro-alcoholic product at entrances to the store, in the toilets, dressing rooms and changing rooms; (3) mark out an entrance and an exit with signage, in businesses that have at least two entrances or an entrance with sufficient width; (4) materialize with signage, whenever possible, traffic flows; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of customers authorized in the shop, taking as a basis one person for 4 m²; (6) provide a dedicated agent for businesses with an area greater than 700 m² in order to manage the flow; (7) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (8) equip the staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing with soap and disinfection; (9) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip the staff with a visor for operations during collections or all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) as far as possible assign individual work tools; (14) set up a time slot at the opening for people over 65, pregnant women and people with disabilities. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure. UPDATE: The policy ends on May 14, because Monaco specified who has to wear a mask.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Since March 14, places open to the public that are not essential to the life of the country must stay close to the public. Effective March 18 and until April 15, Monaco brought precisions regarding that policy. The following buisenesses must close to the public whitout condition: halls for shows, auditions, conferences, meetings; dance halls and games rooms; holiday centers, leisure centers without accommodation; exhibition halls; covered sports establishments; marquees, tents and itinerant structures or with prolonged or fixed installation; outdoor establishments. UPDATE: Since May 4, this policy is extended until further notice. Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco decided to implement a fine in case of an offense. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Since April 1, Monaco decided that employers cannot give notice of dismissal except for those motivated by the fault committed by the employee in the performance of his duties. Effective May 15 and until further notice, Monaco decided that dismissal cannot be pronounced or notified, except for serious misconduct on the part of the employee, for economic dismissal planned and initiated before March 18, 2020, in the event of the death of the employer, in the event of the disappearance of the cause of the employment contract or in the cases provided for by Law No. 1.348 of 25 June 2008 relating to the reclassification of employees declared unfit by the occupational physician. These plans for redundancies are subject to authorization by the labor inspector. The labor inspector must ensure that the planned dismissal is not related to the situation related to the COVID-19 pandemic. The labor inspector carries out a contradictory investigation. It takes its decision within fourteen days, which may be extended for the needs of the investigation. Any employer who contravenes this decision will have to pay a fine of 2,250 to 9,000 euros.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco recommends to temporarily work remotely. UPDATE: Since April 1, a remote working mode must be implemented by the employer with the agreement of the employee whenever the physical presence of the employee is not imperative or security imperatives are not compromised. Effective May 15 and as long as there are measures relating to temporary regulation of travel taken by the Minister of State in order to fight against the spread of the COVID-19 virus, Monaco decided that when the nature of the employee's activity is compatible with his remote exercise and the employer can provide the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise, the employer must allow the employee, subject to his agreement , to carry out his activity in remote work during all or part of his working time. The setting up of remote work, including teleworking, must be notified to the Labor Directorate by the employer using the form established by this directorate. Any employer contravening this decision will have to pay a fine of 600 to 1000 euros.

description: Effective May 20 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all private establishments authorized to open must comply with, at a minimum, these measures: (1) wearing a mask is compulsory in all enclosed places open to the public for all individuals aged 5 and over (2) dispensers of alcohol-based handrub are placed at all entrances, in the toilets and where necessary; (3) staff have masks, hydro-alcoholic products and frequently wash their hands with soap and disinfect them; (4) a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of persons authorized simultaneously in a place, staff included are indicated at the entrance; (5) a distance of 1.50 m between people is respected in all places and materialized on the ground, in particular for the queues; (6) a direction of movement is materialized by appropriate signage; (7) cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment are reinforced; (8) ventilation systems are in perfect condition; (9) strict compliance with the cleaning and disinfection instructions indicated on the products used; (10) dry disinfectant welcome mats are installed where the floor is carpeted; (11) the personnel have products suitable for the cleaning and disinfection operations; (12) payment by credit card is preferred; (13) the premises are ventilated as soon as possible. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that museums and exhibition halls may reopen. Measures to respect: (1) wearing a mask for all those aged 5 and over; (2) hydro-alcoholic product are placed at all entrances, in toilets and where it is necessary; (3) staff always have sufficient masks and hydro-alcoholic products available and frequently wash their hands; (4) a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of people allowed are indicated at the entrance; (5) distance of 1.50 m between people, materialized on the ground, in particular for the queues; (6) a direction of circulation with an entrance and an exit is materialized by signage when possible; (7) the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment are stepped up; (8) the ventilation, fresh air supply and air conditioning / heating systems are maintained in perfect condition; (9) strict compliance with the cleaning and disinfection instructions indicated on the products used; (10) dry disinfectant welcome mats are installed in all places where the floor is carpeted; (11) the staff always have products adapted to the cleaning and disinfection operations required within the framework of their activity; (12) payment by credit card is preferred; (13) premises are ventilated regularly. Any failure is punishable by a fine of 75-200 euros. For a second offense, the fine is 200-600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than 3 times within 30 working days, the fine is 1000-2250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that gaming rooms and slot machines may reopen. Measures to respect: (1) thorough cleaning before reopening (in particular washing carpets); (2) dry disinfectant welcome mats; (3) maximum number of people authorized is 1/4 m²; (4) hand disinfection at each start / finish at gaming tables and slot machines; (5) croupiers have protective visors when they are close to customers; (6) separate slot machines by 1.50 m or install separation elements; (7) install separation screens between players around the same table; (8) clean once a day and disinfect several times a day of play equipment; (9) wearing a mask; (10) hydro-alcoholic product at entrances, toilets and where necessary; (11) the staff have enough masks and hydro-alcoholic products and frequently wash their hands; (12) a reminder of barrier gestures and the maximum number of persons is at the entrance; (13) 1.50 m of distance is respected and materialized on the ground; (14) direction of circulation is materialized when possible; (15) cleaning and disinfection are reinforced; (16) ventilation is in perfect condition; (17) follow the cleaning and disinfection instructions of products used; (18) products suitable to clean and disinfect; (19) payment by credit card preferred; (20) ventilating frequently. Any breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that open-air cinemas are allowed to open again to the public. Measures to respect: (1) hydroalcoolique products at disposition; (2) install a direction of circulation to prevent people from crossing each other; (3)  wearing a mask is mandatory; (4) limit the number of spectator to respect a distance of 1,5 m between everyone; (5) adapt the placing in order to respect a distance of 1,5 m between families and couples; (6) clean and disinfect, after each representation, everything that could have been in contact with a spectator.

description: From June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that bars and restaurants can reopen. Measures to follow: (1) in restaurants, only by reservation; (2) a mask when clients aged 5 and over are not seated; (3) no more than 4 clients/table, or 6 if possible, and 50 cm between clients; (4) separate tables by 1,50 m or install separation elements; (5) favor the terrace; (6) no counter service (seating at a table is mandatory); (7) no cloakroom service; (8) menus on smartphones or plastic cards cleaned between clients; (9) clean tables between use (disinfect tables, chairs, protective screens, table accessories); (10) no buffets or plates to share; (11) limit the music; (12) no karaoke or activities generating proximity and use of common equipment; (13) hydro-alcoholic product where necessary; (14) staff have enough masks and hydro-alcoholic products and wash their hands frequently; (15) at the entrance, a reminder of barrier gestures and the maximum number of people; (16) direction of circulation materialized; (17) ventilation in perfect condition; (18) follow cleaning and disinfection instructions; (19) dry disinfectant mats where there is carpet; (20) enough products to clean and disinfect; (21) payment by credit card preferred; (22) ventilate regularly. No activities of discotheque, piano bar, entertainment, events or live music. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2d time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that congresses and open-air cultural activities are authorized. Measures to respect: (1) maximum number of people inside is 1/4 m²; (2) transparent protective screen or equip staff with a visor for activities with customers; (3) enhance dematerialized tickets; (4) provide disposable equipment to visitors and use applications on smartphones for guided tours; (5) presence of an agent in front of attraction points; (6) limit free entertainment and screening rooms; (8) wearing a mask for all those aged 5 and over; (9) hydro-alcoholic product at entrances, toilets and where necessary; (10) staff have sufficient masks and hydro-alcoholic products and frequently wash their hands; (11) a reminder of barrier gestures and the maximum number of persons is at the entrance; (12) 1.50 m of distance is respected and materialized on the ground; (13) a direction of circulation is materialized where possible; (14) cleaning and disinfection is reinforced; (15) ventilation is in perfect condition; (16) compliance with the cleaning and disinfection instructions; (17) dry disinfectant welcome mats where the floor is carpeted; (18) products adapted to the cleaning and disinfection operations; (19) payment by credit card is preferred; (20) ventilate frequently. description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that swimming pools may reopen, but only to sports practitioners. Measures: (1) snacks and hydration are managed individually; (2) no sharing of personal effects; (3) personal equipment is privileged and common equipment is cleaned before and after each use; (4) no more than 5 people for organized gatherings; (5) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip staff with a visor for activities with customers; (6) adapt benches to respect 1.50 m of distance; (7) increase fresh air supply to at least 80% without reducing it at night and degrease and disinfect the ventilation systems and change the filters; (8) maintain an active chlorine rate of 0.8 to 1.4 mg / L in the ponds and maintain the footbaths at the chlorination rate of 3 to 4 mg / L; (9) limit to 1 person/4m² of surface area open to the public; (10) limit the number of people in the changing rooms to 1 person/4m2; (11) distance of 1.50 m between users; (12) bathers' behavioral rules are respected and encourage hand washing when entering and leaving changing rooms; (13) condemn one in two showers if shared showers; (14) no hair dryers; (15) always use swimming lines; (16) no groups of more than 2 people on beaches around pools. Sports halls, saunas, hammams and jacuzzis are closed. Any breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

description: The establishments in Monaco whose main activity is the operation of a nightclub have been closed to the public since March 14, 2020. Despite the reopening, Monaco decided that these establishments will remain closed, effective June 2 and until further notice. The secondary activities of discotheque, piano bar, entertainment, organization of events, live music, annexed to bar and restaurant activities, are prohibited until further notice. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

Stores and shopping centers have also to close their doors to the public, except for their delivery and order pick-up activities. UPDATE: The policy ends on June 2. Bars and restaurants can now open under conditions.

description: Since May 4, Monaco decided that fashion and ready-to-wear stores can reopen their doors to the public. Effective June 4 and until further notice, the have to follow these measures: (1) use only one cabin in two; (2) when trying on clothes to put on over the head, provide the customer with a square of disposable fabric large enough to cover the entire face, which must be or changed between each customer, placed in a resealable bag and washed at 60 ° C; (3) perform high temperature steam smoothing of pull-on garments after testing and any item returned for exchange or storage in an isolated area for 48 hours; (4) steam the curtains of the test booths at least twice a day. These establishments are also required to comply with the general measures for stores (see the other entry). Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros. The non-recognition of these measures by an establishment may justify its closure.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Since June 2, Monaco authorizes congresses and open-air cultural activities. From June 4 and until further notice, they must follow these measures: (1) 1 person/4 m², staff included; (2) transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip staff with a visor for customer activities; (3) favorized dematerialized tickets; (4) disposable equipment for visitors (or clean and disinfect equipment after use); (5) favorize smartphone applications for guided tours; (6) agent in front of the attraction points; (7) limit free entertainment and screening rooms; (8) limit the number of spectators to respect the sanitary distance of 1.50 m; (9) adapt placement to respect the sanitary distance of 1.50 m; (10) clean and disinfect after each session; (11) limit travel during intermission; (12) organize the exit to avoid a crowd; (13) wearing a mask in enclosed spaces for all those aged 5 and over; (14) hydro-alcoholic products where necessary; (15) at the entrance, a reminder of barrier gestures and the number of people authorized; (16) 1.50 m between people is respected and materialized on the ground; (17) a direction of movement is materialized by signage; (18) ventilation is in perfect condition; (19) dry disinfectant welcome mats are installed where there is carpet; (20) prefer payment by credit card; (21) ventilate as soon as possible. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.
