description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, fashion and ready-to-wear stores can reopen their doors to the public. However, these establishments are required to comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. The non-recognition of these measures by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures concerning fashion and ready-to-wear stores: (1) plan to use only one fitting room in two; (2) when trying on clothes to put on over the head (dress, t-shirt, etc.), it is necessary to (a) provide the customer with a square of fabric large enough to cover the entire face, which must be thrown or changed between each customer, placed in a resealable bag and washed at 60 ° C, and (b) to proceed with a high temperature steam anti-crease on the clothes after they have been tried on and for any item returned for exchange. UPDATE: The policy ends on June 4, because Monaco changed the conditions in which these establishments can open.

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that congresses and open-air cultural activities are authorized. Measures to respect: (1) maximum number of people inside is 1/4 m²; (2) transparent protective screen or equip staff with a visor for activities with customers; (3) enhance dematerialized tickets; (4) provide disposable equipment to visitors and use applications on smartphones for guided tours; (5) presence of an agent in front of attraction points; (6) limit free entertainment and screening rooms; (8) wearing a mask for all those aged 5 and over; (9) hydro-alcoholic product at entrances, toilets and where necessary; (10) staff have sufficient masks and hydro-alcoholic products and frequently wash their hands; (11) a reminder of barrier gestures and the maximum number of persons is at the entrance; (12) 1.50 m of distance is respected and materialized on the ground; (13) a direction of circulation is materialized where possible; (14) cleaning and disinfection is reinforced; (15) ventilation is in perfect condition; (16) compliance with the cleaning and disinfection instructions; (17) dry disinfectant welcome mats where the floor is carpeted; (18) products adapted to the cleaning and disinfection operations; (19) payment by credit card is preferred; (20) ventilate frequently. Any breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days. UPDATE: The policy ends on June 4, because Monaco change the conditions in which these activities are authorized.

description: From June 6 and until further notice, Monaco decided that swimming pools can open, if their manager has validated by the Director of Sanitary Action the sanitary protocol he established (in particular the cleaning and disinfection plan). This validation is not required for swimming pools open only to sports practitioners. Measures: (1) increase fresh air intake to at least 80%, degrease and disinfect the ventilation and change the filters; (2) chlorine rate of 0.8 to 1.4 mg/L in ponds and of 3 to 4 mg/L in footbaths; (3) entry traceability system; (4) nobody with respiratory or digestive signs; (5) 1.50 m between users; (6) remind users the behavioral rules; (7) 1 person/4 m² of public surface area (excluding hall, changing rooms, showers, toilets); (5) no groups of more than 2 around pools; (6) 1 user/2 m² in an indoor pool, 3 users/2 m² in an outdoor pool; (7) footbath and shower before entering; (8) using diving boards and slides only if there is supervision, reinforced disinfection, 1 user at a time, immediate evacuation, a queue respecting distances; (9) no paddling pools; (10) 1 user/4 m² in collective changing rooms; (11) limit the lockers to the number of users, spaced by 1.50 m; (12) soap with automatic dispensers in showers; (13) condemn 1 in 2 showers; (14) no hair dryers. Saunas, hammams, baths or whirlpools are closed. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective June 6 and until further notice, Monaco decided that sports facilities and equipment, (any property specially fitted out or used, permanently or temporarily, with a view to practicing sports and open to practitioners free of charge or against payment) can now open under conditions: (1) before reopening, carry out a defoaming of the soft floors (brushing with a soft brush of the surfaces covered with foam; sweeping of all the surfaces; pressure cleaning with anti-foam additive of all the surfaces); (2) advise practitioners to bring their own virucidal disinfectant wipes in order to disinfect equipment before and after each use; (3) disinfect sports equipment and contact points at least once a day (chin-up bars, bench, etc.); (4) wash structures and floors every day at the end of the day with high pressure equipment associated with a disinfectant followed by effective rinsing; (5) adapt the use of benches so as to respect a sanitary distance of at least one meter fifty (1.50 m) between 2 people. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros. Gyms are not included in this decision.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that swimming pools may reopen, but only to sports practitioners. Measures: (1) snacks and hydration are managed individually; (2) no sharing of personal effects; (3) personal equipment is privileged and common equipment is cleaned before and after each use; (4) no more than 5 people for organized gatherings; (5) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip staff with a visor for activities with customers; (6) adapt benches to respect 1.50 m of distance; (7) increase fresh air supply to at least 80% without reducing it at night and degrease and disinfect the ventilation systems and change the filters; (8) maintain an active chlorine rate of 0.8 to 1.4 mg / L in the ponds and maintain the footbaths at the chlorination rate of 3 to 4 mg / L; (9) limit to 1 person/4m² of surface area open to the public; (10) limit the number of people in the changing rooms to 1 person/4m2; (11) distance of 1.50 m between users; (12) bathers' behavioral rules are respected and encourage hand washing when entering and leaving changing rooms; (13) condemn one in two showers if shared showers; (14) no hair dryers; (15) always use swimming lines; (16) no groups of more than 2 people on beaches around pools. Sports halls, saunas, hammams and jacuzzis are closed. Any breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days. UPDATE: The policy ends on June 6, because swimming pools can now open to everyone.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: As of June 15 and until further notice, Monaco decided that gyms may reopen if their operator has validated by the Director of Health Action the protocol including the health measures put in place, in particular the cleaning plan and reinforced disinfection. Other measures to be observed: (1) favor reservations; (2) keep a list of visitors for 14 days, in order to be able to trace and isolate a possible positive case and its contacts; (3) 1 person / 4 m² is allowed simultaneously; (4) wearing of a mask is obligatory for the members (except during the exercises) and for the personnel (except during a course or the exercise); (5) distance of 1.50 m between workspaces; (6) limit use to equipment that can be easily cleaned; (7) disinfect equipment before and after each use; (8) for group lessons, consider marking on the ground so that each person has a space of 4 m²; (9) one person for 4 m² can access the collective changing rooms; (10) limit the number of lockers to the maximum number of visitors, spaced 1.50 m apart; (11) supplying the showers in the changing rooms with soap using automatic dispensers; (12) condemn one in two showers; (13) no hair dryers. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

description: Effective 9January, Monaco announced that all of the Principality’s shops will be open to external visitors (nationals, residents, those who work in the Principality and those who can show proof of a hotel reservation), non-residents who are not able to provide an essential reason for entering the country access would be restricted. Measure: (1) Ensuring that a safe distance of 1 m between people is maintained; (2) Adhering to a maximum capacity of one person per 4 m2 (in shops open to the public, including employees); (3) Limiting capacity to one person per 10 m2 in the common areas of shopping centres; (4)  Indicating shop capacities on notices placed at the entrance; (5) Managing access to healthcare practices, hairdressing salons, etc. using an appointment system; (6) Introducing directional floor signage and markings to avoid queues at tills.

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they are asymptomatic. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department returning from risk areas defined by the Director of Health Action must make themselves known to this Department and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for a period of fourteen days after returning from a risk area if the employee is not subject to a work stoppage.

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they area symptomatic. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading. description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department returning from risk areas defined by the Director of Health Action must make themselves known to this Department and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity qualified as operators of vital importance. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. The areas considereed at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for a period of fourteen days after returning from a risk area if the employee is not subject to a work stoppage. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.

description: Since February 27, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department returning from risk areas must make themselves known to the Department of Health Action and are subject to an eviction from their workplace if they don't work in an entity of vital importance, which are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the essential needs of Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy or to security of State. Since March 11, areas at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, and provinces of Alessandria, Asti and Turin in Piedmont), France (Aude and Calvados departments and these municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Wurtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). Effective March 13 and until further notice, teleworking can be implemented with the agreement of the employee  for all or part of the weekly working time.

description: Since February 27, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department returning from risk areas defined by the Director of Health Action must make themselves known to this Department and can be evict from their workplace if they don't work in an entity of vital importance (those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State). Effective March 11 and until further notice, areas at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, Piedmont (only in Alessandria, Asti and Turin), France (Aude and Calvados departments and these municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Wurtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). A remote working mode can be implemented with the agreement of the employee for 14 days. UPDATE: This policy ends on March 13, because the Monegasque government decided to remove the 14-day limit for teleworking.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective March 16 and until further notice, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Service, parents of a child under 16 (or 18 in the event of a disability) whose school or kiendergarden is temporarily closed in order to limit the spread of Covid-19, must assess with their employer the possibility of implementing a remote working mode for the duration of the closure of the school or kindergarden. The employer's refusal to set up remote work must be justified. If they cannot benefit from an adjustment of their working conditions allowing them to stay at home to look after their child, the insured can benefit from a work stoppage compensated by the Monegasque health insurance fund to which they are members, on condition that the other parent is not placed in a situation of temporary total unemployment.

UPDATE: Effective March 18 and until March 31, Monaco decided that employers must, as a first step, assess the possibility of generalizing the use of remote work. Employees must bring their proof of professional travel when they go to work.

description: Since February 27, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department who work in entities of vital importance and come back from a risk area can continue to work if they area symptomatic. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy and to security of State. Effective on March 11 and until further notice, the areas at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, and provinces of Alessandria, Asti and Turin in Piedmont), France (Aude and Calvados departments and the following municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Würtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading. UPDATE: On March 20, the Monegasque government repealed the ministerial decision that established that policy.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective from March 26 to April 26, and retroactive to March 16, Monaco decided to suspend the time limits for administrative and contentious appeals, as well as for proceedings before the Supreme Court, with the exception of those implied by the exercise of the emergency procedure appearing in article 41 of Sovereign Order no.2984 of 16 April 1963 on the organization and functioning of the Supreme Court.

description: Since March 18, all the projects under the control of public works (Maîtrise d’Ouvrage Publique), whether direct or delegated, were closed (except the site of the United States quay). On April 1, Monaco decided to reopen the sites of Larvotto and the Casino square. The following measures will be adopted: temperature measurement at the site entrance; equipment in gloves, masks and gel compulsory; restrictive arrangement of cantonments; lunches on site with respect for distances; enhanced hygiene of equipment and vehicles.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco recommends teleworking for those that this is possible. UPDATE: Effective April 1 and until further notice, a remote working mode must be implemented by the employer with the agreement of the employee whenever the physical presence of the employee is not imperative or whenever security imperatives are not compromised. The refusal to implement remote work must be justified to the Labor Inspectorate.

description: On March 18, Monaco decided to suspend until further notice the projects under the control of public works (Maîtrise d’Ouvrage Publique), whether direct or delegated. The sites concerned are: Hélios; Jardins d'Apolline, Engelin; NCHPG; islet Pasteur; Darse North; Larvotto complex; Honoria; Ida; Testimony II; Picapeira; Maintain the CHPG level; Entrance to the exotic garden of the city; 17, street Princesse Florestine, as well as all road and public space works. Only one operation under public contracting authority derogates from this general rule: the site of the United States quay. UPDATE: The policy ends on April 1 because Monaco decided to reopen the sites of Larvotto and the casino square.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco recommends teleworking for those that this is possible. UPDATE: Monaco decided that from March 18 and until March 31, employers must, as a first step, assess the possibility of generalizing the use of remote work. If remote work is not compatible with the service provided, the employer must give each employee concerned a document establishing the need for the employee to go to work phisically. Employees must bring their proof of professional travel when they go to work. On March 27, Monaco decided to extend that policy until April 15.

description: Effective March 19 and until March 31, Monaco closes access to the shore of Monegasque maritime waters. This includes beaches, natural rocky seaside sectors and sea defense structures, such as groynes, breakwaters and dikes located on the public domain. UPDATE: On March 27, Monaco decided to extend this policy until April 15. Furthermore, any breach is now punishable of a fine from 75 to 200 euros.

description: From April 9 to June 9 and retroactive until March 16, Monaco decided to suspend the following deadlines: procedural deadlines in civil, commercial, social and administrative matters, including, in particular, those inherent in ordinary and extraordinary appeals, in addition to those of foreclosure provided for by codes or special laws; the time limits for hearings, as well as those at the end of which a magistrate must have ruled, with the exception of those relating to pre-trial detention; the fifteen-day period provided for by articles 576 and 601 of the Commercial Code and 328 of the Penal Code is also suspended. The period of suspension will be extended for as long as the measures temporarily regulating travel in order to combat the spread of the COVID-19 virus take effect.

description: Effective from April 9 to May 18 and retroactive until March 18, Monaco decided to suspend the following deadlines: the deadlines imposed on citizens of Monaco (of the State, the Municipality and any public administration) to file a request or a declaration, to formalize an act, or to complete any other formality, registration, notification or publication; processing times imposed on administrative authorities; the time limits imposed by an administrative authority on any citizen (of the State, the Municipality and any public administration) to comply with prescriptions of any kind. This period will be extended as long as the measures temporarily regulating travel taken by the Minister of State to combat the spread of the COVID-19 virus take effect. At the end of the suspension period, possibly extended under the conditions provided for in the previous paragraph, an additional suspension period of one month will be added.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that the public construction activities can resume under conditions. Before resumption or execution of any construction work begins, a file detailing all the measures envisaged, accompanied by an explanatory plan of the organization of the cantonments (by specifying in particular the changing rooms occupied, the places in the refectory, the traffic flows to avoid crossings, the positioning of the water points, the distances expressed in meters between each occupied changing room, each seat, between the tables themselves, etc.) and the detailed list of all the staff as well as their origin must be submitted to the Department of Foresight, Town Planning and Mobility. The measures must include: compliance with barrier gestures (minimum distance of one meter, frequent hand washing, wearing of a mask, regular disinfection of site premises, machinery and vehicles); taking the temperature at the entrance to the site; ban on eating outside the work site and eating face-to-face; prohibition of recourse to long journeys, except in cases of imperative necessity; ban on the use of temporary workers; mandatory designation, by the Contracting Authority, of a COVID 19 referent, able to stop the work. Any infringement will be noted by sworn officers and prosecuted in accordance with the law.

description: As of May 4 and until further notice, Monaco has decided that all administrative establishments in the Principality called upon to welcome the public will reopen their doors. Hydroalcoholic gel dispensers must be installed and all must respect a sanitary distance of 1.50 m. Regular asepsis of the places of passage and contact will be carried out.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, the Circulation Ticket Service (Service des Titres de Circulation) of Monaco decided that document withdrawals can only be done by appointment. Vehicle technical inspections can only be carried out after payment and by appointment at the Vehicle Technical Control Center. Access to letterboxes for automotive professionals can be done without an appointment. Payments can be made by check or credit card.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that the public construction activities can resume under conditions. For the demolition and/or reconstruction of a building, the elevations and civil engineering works, before any resumption or execution of the works, must be submitted to the Department of Prospective, Urbanism and of Mobility a file detailing all the measures envisaged, accompanied by an explanatory plan of the organization of the cantonments (specifying in particular the changing rooms occupied, the refectory places, the traffic flows to avoid crossings, the positioning water points, the distances expressed in meters between each changing room occupied, each seating position, between the tables themselves, etc.) and the detailed list of all staff as well as their origin. For work subject to building authorization other than those referred upper as well as for the renovations of buildings, the Department of Prospective, Urban Planning and Mobility must be informed by the COVID-19 referent of the takeover or execution. It is up to him to obtain the prior agreement of the client if the latter is not COVID-19 referent. Any violation of this decision will be noted by sworn officers and prosecuted in accordance with the law.

description: Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco decided that access to natural or man-made beaches is authorized between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m., subject to permanent compliance with health distancing rules. Only their dynamic use for individual sports practice is authorized. Picnics as well as the practice of team sports are prohibited there. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

description: Effective May 5 and until further notice, Monaco decided to open its courthouse to the public, from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.. Access will be limited to the reception hall and courtrooms. Lawyers will be able to access the room reserved for them, limited to four people. Measures to be observed: wash your hands very regularly; use hydro-alcoholic gel; wearing a mask is strongly recommended; greet without shaking hands and avoid hugs; keep a distance of at least 1.50 m from any other person; cough or sneeze into your elbow or into a disposable tissue; use disposable tissues. Upon entering the building, two separate circuits were set up, one for legal professionals and the other for the public. Hygiaphones have been installed in reception stations, and regular cleaning will be carried out. The exchanges between lawyers and the court will, in the long term, mainly be dematerialized. The filing of cases on the day of the hearing will be the rule and the pleadings will be postponed to subsequent hearings after the next judicial reopening. Staff in contact with the public will be provided with masks and gloves. All hearings will be gradually restored to be fully from the last week of May. Hearings in the presence of the parties will be limited to criminal matters to those where the presence of persons is mandatory or in the event of non-representation by a lawyer.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective May 5 and until further notice, Monaco decided to open its courthouse to the public, from 2 p.m. at 16 o'clock. Access will be limited to the reception hall and courtrooms. Lawyers will be able to access the room reserved for them, limited to four people. Measures to be observed: wash your hands very regularly; use hydro-alcoholic gel; wearing a mask is strongly recommended; greet without shaking hands and avoid hugs; keep a distance of at least 1.50 m from any other person; cough or sneeze into your elbow or into a disposable tissue; use disposable tissues. Upon entering the building, two separate circuits were set up, one for legal professionals and the other for the public. Hygiaphones have been installed in reception stations, and regular cleaning will be carried out. The exchanges between lawyers and the court will, in the long term, mainly be dematerialized. The filing of cases on the day of the hearing will be the rule and the pleadings will be postponed to subsequent hearings after the next judicial reopening. Staff in contact with the public will be provided with masks and gloves. All hearings will be gradually restored to be fully from the last week of May. Hearings in the presence of the parties will be limited to criminal matters to those where the presence of persons is mandatory or in the event of non-representation by a lawyer. UPDATE: Monaco decided that wearing a mask is mandatory for everyone of 5 years old or over. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

description: Since March 14, places open to the public which are "not essential to the life of the country" must close their doors to the public. Effective March 18 and until April 15, Monaco precised that the following public establishment must close their doors to the public: Libraries, documentation centers, exhibition halls, indoor sports establishments, museums, outdoor establishments. UPDATE: Since May 4, this policy is extended until further notice. Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco decided to implement a fine in case of an offense. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco closes access to children's playgrounds; sports facilities and equipment (any property belonging specially fitted out or used, permanently or temporarily, with a view to practicing sports and open to practitioners free of charge or against payment). For a first offense, the fine is from 75 to 200 euros. In case of a repeated offense, the fine is from 200 to 600 euros. UPDATE: Since May 4, this policy is going on until further notice. Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco increased the fine. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

description: Effective February 28 and until further notice, Monaco recommends teleworking for those that this is possible. UPDATE: Since April 1, a remote working mode must be implemented by the employer with the agreement of the employee whenever the physical presence of the employee is not imperative or security imperatives are not compromised. Effective May 15 and as long as there are measures relating to temporary regulation of travel taken by the Minister of State in order to fight against the spread of the COVID-19 virus, Monaco decided that when the nature of the employee's activity is compatible with his remote exercise and the employer can provide the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise, the employer must allow the employee, subject to his agreement , to carry out his activity in remote work during all or part of his working time. The setting up of remote work, including teleworking, must be notified to the Labor Directorate by the employer using the form established by this directorate. Any employer contravening this decision will have to pay a fine of 600 to 1000 euros.

description: Since May 14, Monaco decided that access to natural or man-made beaches is authorized between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m. The practice of team sports is prohibited. Effective May 20 and until further notice, Monaco specified that the distance of at least 1.50 m between people applies, with the exception of members of the same household. Groups are limited to a family or a group of up to 5 people. Wearing a mask is not compulsory subject to strict compliance with sanitary distancing, with the exception of members of the same household. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

description: Since May 4, Monaco has decided that all administrative establishments called upon to welcome the public are reopenning their doors to the public. Effective May 20 and until further notice, they have to follow these measures: (1) wearing a mask for all individuals aged 5 and over (2) dispensers of alcohol-based handrub are placed at all entrances, in the toilets and where necessary; (3) staff have masks, hydro-alcoholic products and frequently wash their hands with soap and disinfect them; (4) a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of persons authorized simultaneously in a place, staff included are indicated at the entrance; (5) a distance of 1.50 m between people is respected in all places and materialized on the ground, in particular for the queues; (6) a direction of movement is materialized by appropriate signage; (7) cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment are reinforced; (8) ventilation systems are in perfect condition; (9) strict compliance with the cleaning and disinfection instructions indicated on the products used; (10) dry disinfectant welcome mats are installed where the floor is carpeted; (11) the personnel have products suitable for the cleaning and disinfection operations; (12) payment by credit card is preferred; (13) the premises are ventilated as soon as possible. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

description: Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco decided that access to natural or man-made beaches is authorized between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m., subject to permanent compliance with health distancing rules. Only their dynamic use for individual sports practice is authorized. Picnics as well as the practice of team sports are prohibited there. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros. UPDATE: The policy ends on May 20, because Monaco changed some rules regarding what is forbidden to do on beaches.

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that museums and exhibition halls may reopen. Measures to respect: (1) wearing a mask for all those aged 5 and over; (2) hydro-alcoholic product are placed at all entrances, in toilets and where it is necessary; (3) staff always have sufficient masks and hydro-alcoholic products available and frequently wash their hands; (4) a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of people allowed are indicated at the entrance; (5) distance of 1.50 m between people, materialized on the ground, in particular for the queues; (6) a direction of circulation with an entrance and an exit is materialized by signage when possible; (7) the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment are stepped up; (8) the ventilation, fresh air supply and air conditioning / heating systems are maintained in perfect condition; (9) strict compliance with the cleaning and disinfection instructions indicated on the products used; (10) dry disinfectant welcome mats are installed in all places where the floor is carpeted; (11) the staff always have products adapted to the cleaning and disinfection operations required within the framework of their activity; (12) payment by credit card is preferred; (13) premises are ventilated regularly. Any failure is punishable by a fine of 75-200 euros. For a second offense, the fine is 200-600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than 3 times within 30 working days, the fine is 1000-2250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that swimming pools can reopen, but only to sports practitioners. Measures to respect: (1) snacks and hydration are managed individually; (2) no sharing of personal effects; (3) favorize personal equipment (common equipment is cleaned between each use); (4) no more than 5 people for organized gatherings; (5) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip staff with a visor for activities with customers; (6) distance benches by 1.50 m; (7) increase the volume of fresh air supply to at least 80% without reducing it at night and degrease and disinfect the ventilation systems and change the filters; (8) maintain an active chlorine rate of 0.8 to 1.4 mg / L in the ponds and maintain the footbaths at the chlorination rate of 3 to 4 mg / L; (9) limit to 1 person/4m² of surface area open to the public; (10) limit the number of people in the changing rooms to 1 person/4m2; (11) distance of 1.50 m between users; (12) bathers' behavioral rules are respected and encourage hand washing when entering and leaving changing rooms; (13) condemn one in two showers if shared showers; (14) no hair dryers; (15) always use swimming lines; (16) no groups of more than 2 people on beaches around pools. Sports halls, saunas, hammams and jacuzzis are closed. Any breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: From June 6 and until further notice, Monaco decided that swimming pools can open. Measures:  the manager has validated by the Director of Sanitary Action his sanitary protocol (in particular the cleaning and disinfection plan) (not required for pools open only to sports practitioners); (1) increase fresh air intake to at least 80%, degrease and disinfect the ventilation and change filters; (2) chlorine rate of 0.8 to 1.4 mg/L in ponds and of 3 to 4 mg/L in footbaths; (3) entry traceability system; (4) nobody with respiratory or digestive signs; (5) 1.50 m between users; (6) remind users the behavioral rules; (7) 1 person/4 m² of public surface area (excluding hall, changing rooms, showers, toilets); (5) no groups of more than 2 around pools; (6) 1 user/2 m² in indoor pools, 3 users/2 m² in outdoor pools; (7) footbath and shower before entering; (8) using diving boards and slides only if there is supervision, reinforced disinfection, 1 user at a time, immediate evacuation, a queue respecting distances; (9) no paddling pools; (10) 1 user/4 m² in collective changing rooms; (11) limit the lockers to the number of users, spaced by 1.50 m; (12) soap with automatic dispensers in showers; (13) condemn 1 in 2 showers; (14) no hair dryers; (15) no saunas, hammams, baths or whirlpools; (16) mask for all of those aged of 5 and over. A breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 € the 1st time, 200-600 € the 2nd time and 1000-2250 € if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.

description: Effective June 6 and until further notice, Monaco decided that children's playground can now open under conditions: (1) before reopening, carry out a defoaming of the soft floors (brushing with a soft brush of the surfaces covered with foam; sweeping of all the surfaces; pressure cleaning with anti-foam additive of all the surfaces); (2) disinfect play structures and contact points at least once a day; (3) wash the soil structures every day when closing with high pressure equipment associated with a disinfectant followed by effective rinsing; (4) adapt the use of the benches so as to respect a sanitary distance of at least one meter fifty (1.50 m) between 2 people. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

description: Effective June 6 and until further notice, Monaco decided that sports facilities and equipment (any property specially fitted out or used, permanently or temporarily, with a view to practicing sports and open to practitioners free of charge or against payment) can now open under conditions: (1) before reopening, carry out a defoaming of the soft floors (brushing with a soft brush of the surfaces covered with foam; sweeping of all the surfaces; pressure cleaning with anti-foam additive of all the surfaces); (2) advise practitioners to bring their own virucidal disinfectant wipes in order to disinfect equipment before and after each use; (3) disinfect sports equipment and contact points at least once a day (chin-up bars, bench, etc.); (4) wash structures and floors every day at the end of the day with high pressure equipment associated with a disinfectant followed by effective rinsing; (5) adapt the use of benches so as to respect a sanitary distance of at least one meter fifty (1.50 m) between 2 people. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.

Events cancelled: Music Festival (wich was supposed to take place on April 21 at Leo Ferré concert hall); Zaziessencieltour (wchich was supposed to take place on April 20 at Leo Ferré concert hall); Young Audience Concert (wich was supposed to take place on May 27 at Leo Ferré concert hall); Gala concert (which was supposed to take place on June 24 at Rainier III Academy); Plant hunting (which was supposed to take place on April 11 at Exotic Garden of Monaco); Egg hunt (which was supposed to take place on June 12 at Princess Antoinette Park); Splash Party (which was supposed to take place on June 10 at at Rainier III Nautical Stadium). description: Effective March 13 and until further notice, Monaco forbade gatherings of more than 100 people. UPDATE: Since March 18, all gatherings between people who are not in the same house are prohibited. This policy was initially set to last until March 31. On March 27, Monaco announced that this policy would continue until April 15. On April 10, Monaco announced that this policy will finally end on May 3.

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, any gathering of more than 5 people on public roads and spaces is prohibited. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that places of worship will have to respect the following measures: (1) ensure that everyone wears a mask; (2) provide a dispenser of hydro-alcoholic product at all entrances to the place of worship, in the toilets and in the changing rooms; (3) sign an entrance and an exit with signage, in places of worship that have at least two entrances or an entrance with sufficient width; (4) materialize, whenever possible, traffic flows with appropriate signage; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of faithful allowed in the place of worship, taking as a basis a maximum of one person for 4 m², staff and officiants included; (6) arrange for those present to maintain a distance of 1.5 m; (7) equip officiants and staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing with soap and disinfection; (8) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment, in particular by increasing the frequency of maintenance of contact points; (9) avoid or adapt religious practices constituting a risk of the spread of COVID-19; (10) remove the objects of worship made available to the community.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since May 4, Monaco decided that places of worship have the respect the following measures: (1) ensure that everyone wears a mask; (2) provide a dispenser of hydro-alcoholic product at all entrances to the place of worship, in the toilets and in the changing rooms; (3) sign an entrance and an exit, in places of worship that have at least two entrances or an entrance with sufficient width; (4) materialize, whenever possible, traffic flows with appropriate signage; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of faithful allowed in the place of worship, taking as a basis a maximum of one person for 4 m², staff and officiants included; (6) arrange for those present to maintain a distance of 1.5 m; (7) equip officiants and staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing with soap and disinfection; (8) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment, in particular by increasing the frequency of maintenance of contact points; (9) avoid or adapt religious practices constituting a risk of the spread of COVID-19; (10) remove the objects of worship made available to the community. Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco precised that children under five years old do not have to wear a mask. Any breach is now punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, any gathering of more than 5 people on public roads and spaces is prohibited. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. UPDATE: Effective May 14 and until further notice, Monaco increased the fine. Any breach is punishable by a fine of 75 to 200 euros for a first offense. In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is 200 to 600 euros. If the breaches are reported more than three times within thirty working days from the day on which the first breach was committed, the fine is from 1000 to 2250 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that places of worship will have to respect the following measures: (1) ensure that everyone wears a mask; (2) provide a dispenser of hydro-alcoholic product at all entrances to the place of worship, in the toilets and in the changing rooms; (3) sign an entrance and an exit with signage, in places of worship that have at least two entrances or an entrance with sufficient width; (4) materialize, whenever possible, traffic flows with appropriate signage; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of faithful allowed in the place of worship, taking as a basis a maximum of one person for 4 m², staff and officiants included; (6) arrange for those present to maintain a distance of 1.5 m; (7) equip officiants and staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing with soap and disinfection; (8) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment, in particular by increasing the frequency of maintenance of contact points; (9) avoid or adapt religious practices constituting a risk of the spread of COVID-19; (10) remove the objects of worship made available to the community. UPDATE: The policy ends on May 14, because Monaco specified who has to wear a mask.

description: Effective June 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that outdoor cultural activities are authorized. Measures to respect: (1) set up a transparent protective screen or equip staff with a visor for all activities with customers; (2) enhance dematerialized tickets; (3) offer disposable equipment to visitors and use applications on smartphones for guided tours; (4) provide an agent in front of the attraction points; (5) limit free entertainment and screening rooms; (6) limit the spectators to respect a distance of 1.50 m between them; (7) wearing a mask for all those aged 5 and over; (8) hydro-alcoholic product is placed at entrances, in toilets and where necessary; (9) the staff always have sufficient masks and hydro-alcoholic products and frequently wash their hands; (10) a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of authorized persons is at the entrance; (11) the distance of 1.50 m between people is respected and materialized on the ground; (12) a direction of circulation with an entrance and an exit is materialized by signage where possible; (13) cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment are reinforced; (14) the staff always have products suitable for the cleaning and disinfection operations required in the context of their activity; (15) payment by credit card is preferred. Any breach is punishable by a fine: 75-200 euros the first time, 200-600 euros the second time and 1000-2250 euros if it is more than 3 times within 30 working days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective February 27 and until further notice, employees affiliated to the Social Services Compensation Fund who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and coming back from a risk area can continue to work if they are asymptomatic. The areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau), Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia and the regions of Lombardy, Veneto and Emilia-Romagna in Italy. Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Since February 27, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department who work in entities qualified as operators of vital importance and come back from a risk area can continue to work if they area symptomatic. Effective March 2 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau) Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna), France (Oise (only this department in Hauts-de-France)). Entities qualified as operators of vital importance are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the satisfaction of the essential needs for the life of the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy as well as to security of State. If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading. UPDATE: The policy ends on March 5 because of a change in the areas considered at risk.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All government services regulated
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
target_other: Oise Department (Hauts-de-France)
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Since January 30, Monaco decided that people who have been in an area considered at risk and presenting a lower respiratory infection (cough and fever) should, among other things, wear a mask when they go outside and wash their hands frequently. Effective March 2 and until further notice, the areas considered at risk are: China (including Hong Kong and Macau) Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna), France (Oise (only this department of Hauts-de-France)). UPDATE: The policy ends on March 5 because of a change in the areas considered at risk.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Since February 27, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department who work in entities of vital importance and come back from a risk area can continue to work if they area symptomatic. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy and to security of State. Effective on March 11 and until further notice, the areas at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, and provinces of Alessandria, Asti and Turin in Piedmont), France (Aude and Calvados departments and the following municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Würtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

Effective March 18 and until March 31, theses measures are: to wash hands very regularly either with soap and water for at least twenty seconds or, in the absence of water and soap, with a hydro-alcoholic product, rubbing until the skin is dry; to greet without shaking hands and hugging; to keep a minimum distance of at least one meter from any other person; to cough or sneeze into our elbow or into a disposable tissue; to use disposable handkerchiefs.

description: Monaco is enforcing a lockdown from March 18 to March 31. The movement of any person outside their home is prohibited, with the exception of trips for the following reasons: (1) trips between the home and the place (s) of exercise of professional activity, when they are essential for carrying out activities that cannot be organized in the form of teleworking or constitute business trips that cannot be postponed; (2) travel to purchase supplies necessary for professional activity and essential purchases in local establishments and businesses authorized to welcome the public; (3) travel for health reasons; (4) travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable persons or for the care of children; (5) short trips, close to home, linked to the individual physical activity of people, to the exclusion of any collective sporting activity, and to the needs of pets. The police will carry out checks. Regarding the exception related to professional travel, a certificate of necessity must be completed by the employer.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Since February 27, civil servants and public officials affiliated to the State Medical Benefits Department who work in entities of vital importance and come back from a risk area can continue to work if they area symptomatic. These entities are those specifically related to the production and distribution of goods or services essential to the Monegasque population, to the exercise of the authority of the State, to the functioning of the economy and to security of State. Effective on March 11 and until further notice, the areas at risk are: China, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Singapore, Thailand, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Iran, Bahrain, Vietnam, Italy (Lombardy, Veneto, Emilia-Romagna, Marche, and provinces of Alessandria, Asti and Turin in Piedmont), France (Aude and Calvados departments and the following municipalities: Les contamines-Montjoie, La Balme-de-Sillingy, Crépy-en-Valois, Creil, Mulhouse, Auray, Crash, Carnac, Doubs, Ajaccio), Germany (Würtemberg, Bayern, Nordrhein-Westfalen), Spain (Madrid, Andalusia, Basque Country, Castille-La-Mancha, Castile and Leon, Catalonia, La Rioja, Valencia), San Marino, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Netherlands, Switzerland (Ticino, Vaud, Geneva, Basel, Zurich), United States (Washington State, New York State, California, Massachusset). If essential workers are allowed to come to their work place, a specific protocol must be adopted. For example, it can be the obligation to wear a mask or to take a regular temperature reading. UPDATE: On March 20, the Monegasque government repealed the ministerial decision that established that policy.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside All government services regulated

description: Effective April 10 and until further notice, Monaco decided that before resumption or execution of any construction work begins, a file detailing all the measures envisaged, accompanied by an explanatory plan of the organization of the cantonments (by specifying in particular the changing rooms occupied, the places in the refectory, the traffic flows to avoid crossings, the positioning of the water points, the distances expressed in meters between each occupied changing room, each seat, between the tables themselves, etc.) and the detailed list of all the staff as well as their origin must be submitted to the Department of Foresight, Town Planning and Mobility. This file is submitted by the client, in agreement with the intervening companies. The measures must include: compliance with barrier gestures (minimum distance of one meter, frequent hand washing, wearing of a mask, regular disinfection of site premises, machinery and vehicles); taking the temperature at the entrance to the site; ban on eating outside the work site and eating face-to-face; prohibition of recourse to long journeys, except in cases of imperative necessity; ban on the use of temporary workers; mandatory designation, by the Contracting Authority, of a COVID 19 referent, able to stop the work. Any infringement will be noted by sworn officers and prosecuted in accordance with the law.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

In the event of a repeat offense, the fine is from 200 to 600 euros.

description: Since March 18, Monaco is under lockdown. On March 27, Monaco changed the conditions why people are allowed to be outside and extended the initial length of the lockdown's policy. Reasons why people are allowed to be outside, from March 27 to April 15: (1) travel between home and the place(s) of work, when they are essential for the exercise of activities that cannot be organized in distance or constitute professional trips not cannot be deferred; (2) travel to purchase supplies necessary for professional activity and essential purchases; (3) travel for health reasons, namely consultations and care that cannot be provided remotely and cannot be postponed; consultations and care of patients with long-term illness; (4) travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable persons or childcare; (5) short trips, linked either to the individual physical activity of people, to a walk with only people grouped together in the same home, to the needs of pets; (6) travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons; (7) travel for participation in missions of general interest at the request of the administrative authority. Regarding the exception related to professional travel, a certificate must be completed by the employer. The police will carry out checks. Any breach is punishable by a fine from 75 to 200 euros.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Since March 18, Monaco is under lockdown. On March 27, Monaco changed the conditions why people are allowed to be outside and extended the initial length of the lockdown's policy. Reasons why people are allowed to be outside, from March 27 to April 15: (1) travel between home and the place(s) of work, when they are essential for the exercise of activities that cannot be organized in distance or constitute professional trips not cannot be deferred; (2) travel to purchase supplies necessary for professional activity and essential purchases; (3) travel for health reasons, namely consultations and care that cannot be provided remotely and cannot be postponed; consultations and care of patients with long-term illness; (4) travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable persons or childcare; (5) short trips, linked either to the individual physical activity of people, to a walk with only people grouped together in the same home, to the needs of pets; (6) travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons; (7) travel for participation in missions of general interest at the request of the administrative authority. The Public Security will ensure the strict application of these provisions and will be empowered to issue fines to offenders with a fine of up to 200 euros. The police will carry out checks. Regarding the exception related to professional travel, a certificate must be completed by the employer. UPDATE: On April 10 Monaco warned that during this Easter weekend (April 11 to 13), controls will be tightened. The Public Security, equipped with a drone, will sweep the national territory to ensure that the measures are respected.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Since March 18, Monaco is under lockdown. On March 27, Monaco changed the conditions why people are allowed to be outside and extended the initial length of the lockdown's policy. Reasons why people are allowed to be outside, from March 27 to April 15: (1) travel between home and the place(s) of work, when they are essential for the exercise of activities that cannot be organized in distance or constitute professional trips not cannot be deferred; (2) travel to purchase supplies necessary for professional activity and essential purchases; (3) travel for health reasons, namely consultations and care that cannot be provided remotely and cannot be postponed; consultations and care of patients with long-term illness; (4) travel for compelling family reasons, for assistance to vulnerable persons or childcare; (5) short trips, linked either to the individual physical activity of people, to a walk with only people grouped together in the same home, to the needs of pets; (6) travel to respond to a judicial or administrative summons; (7) travel for participation in missions of general interest at the request of the administrative authority. The Public Security will ensure the strict application of these provisions and will be empowered to issue fines to offenders with a fine of up to 200 euros. The police will carry out checks. Regarding the exception related to professional travel, a certificate must be completed by the employer. UPDATE: On April 10, Monaco decided to extend thit policy until May 3.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Effective May 2 and until further notice, Monaco decided that the following rules have to be repescted in elevators: (1) wearing a mask is mandatory; (2) if several people are in the elevator, respect the safety distance of at least 1.5 m and stand back to back; (3) avoid pressing buttons without protecting your hands (preferably use a tissue to throw away immediately after use in a public trash. If necessary, disinfect your hands with a hydro-alcoholic product); (4) do not touch the doors.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that the public construction activities can resume under conditions. Before resumption or execution of any construction work begins, a file detailing all the measures envisaged, accompanied by an explanatory plan of the organization of the cantonments (by specifying in particular the changing rooms occupied, the places in the refectory, the traffic flows to avoid crossings, the positioning of the water points, the distances expressed in meters between each occupied changing room, each seat, between the tables themselves, etc.) and the detailed list of all the staff as well as their origin must be submitted to the Department of Foresight, Town Planning and Mobility. The measures must include: compliance with barrier gestures (minimum distance of one meter, frequent hand washing, wearing of a mask, regular disinfection of site premises, machinery and vehicles); taking the temperature at the entrance to the site; ban on eating outside the work site and eating face-to-face; prohibition of recourse to long journeys, except in cases of imperative necessity; ban on the use of temporary workers; mandatory designation, by the Contracting Authority, of a COVID 19 referent, able to stop the work. Any infringement will be noted by sworn officers and prosecuted in accordance with the law.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other government service not specified above
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of May 4 and until further notice, Monaco has decided that all administrative establishments in the Principality called upon to welcome the public will reopen their doors. Hydroalcoholic gel dispensers must be installed and all must respect a sanitary distance of 1.50 m. Regular asepsis of the places of passage and contact will be carried out.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other government service not specified above

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that food stores must follow these measure: (1) mask is mandatory for everyone; (2) provide a dispenser of hydro-alcoholic product at entrances to the store, in the toilets, dressing rooms and changing rooms; (3) mark out an entrance and an exit with signage, in businesses that have at least two entrances or an entrance with sufficient width; (4) materialize with signage, whenever possible, traffic flows; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of customers authorized in the shop, taking as a basis one person for 4 m²; (6) provide a dedicated agent for businesses with an area greater than 700 m² in order to manage the flow; (7) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (8) equip the staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing with soap and disinfection; (9) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip the staff with a visor for operations during collections or all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) as far as possible assign individual work tools; (14) set up a time slot at the opening for people over 65, pregnant women and people with disabilities. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all stores and shopping centers can reopen. General measures they have to follow: (1) ensure that customers wear a mask; (2) provide hydro-alcoholic product at entrances, in toilets, dressing rooms, changing rooms; (3) mark out an entrance and an exit with signage, when possible; (4) signage, whenever possible, traffic flows; (5) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of customers authorized (with a basis of one person/4 m²); (6) provide a dedicated agent for businesses with an area greater than 700 m² to manage the flow; (7) clean and disinfect electronic payment terminals after each use and all items touched by customers; (8) equip the staff with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and provide frequent hand washing and disinfection; (9) set up a transparent protective screen or, if impossible, equip the staff with a visor for all activities with customers; (10) favor payment by credit card; (11) strengthen the cleaning and disinfection of premises and equipment; (12) favor shelving outside the establishment's opening hours; (13) it possible, assign individual work tools. A distance of 1,5 m between each other is mandatory. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Retail Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Monaco decided that all shopping centers can reopen. Shopping centers must comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. Failure by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures: (1) provide hydro-alcoholic product at entrances and in the toilets and continuously supply soap dispensers; (2) mark out an entrance and an exit; (3) signage traffic flows; (4) indicate at the entrance a reminder of the barrier gestures and the maximum number of authorized customers, taking as a base one for 12 m², staff included (to do this: organize queues at the entrance of the shops with a 1.5 m spacing between customers and set up a system for counting flows at entrances and exits); (5) equip security personnel with masks, hydro-alcoholic products and tweezers in the event that disposable masks are distributed to customers; (6) use video surveillance to detect, treat and remove high density areas; (7) adapt the use of benches to respect a distance of 1.5 m between two seats; (8) increase the disinfection of the areas most often affected; (9) increase the quantity of fresh air injected and perform “free cooling” regularly during opening hours while limiting appliance condensation; (10) Establish and disseminate a protocol for take-out sales and the delivery service of catering outlets; (11) set up a protocol for the security personnel to take charge of a person presenting symptoms.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Shopping Centers
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, Hairdressers, beauty salons and nail bars are allowed to reopen their doors to the public. However, these establishments are required to comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. The non-recognition of these measures by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures concerning hairdressing salons, beauty institutes and nail bars: (1) ensure a distance of 1.5 m between workstations; (2) welcome clients only by appointment with sufficient margin to avoid waiting; (3) provide staff and customers with alcohol-based hand rubs at each workstation; (4) systematically change the work instruments between each client and soak the instruments previously used in a disinfectant solution; (5) clean and disinfect objects, surfaces and work equipment that may have been contaminated; (6) change disposable single-use (bathrobe, headband, towel, etc.) or washable linen between each client and placed without delay after use in a dedicated resealable bag; (7) use single-use and disposable razors; (8) provide for the installation of a transparent protective screen or the wearing of a mask and visor; (9) not to offer magazines or digital tablets; (10) not offer food or drink to customers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: Effective May 4 and until further notice, fashion and ready-to-wear stores can reopen their doors to the public. However, these establishments are required to comply with the general measures (see the other entry) and measures specific to their activity. The non-recognition of these measures by an establishment may justify its closure. Specific measures concerning fashion and ready-to-wear stores: (1) plan to use only one fitting room in two; (2) when trying on clothes to put on over the head (dress, t-shirt, etc.), it is necessary to (a) provide the customer with a square of fabric large enough to cover the entire face, which must be thrown or changed between each customer, placed in a resealable bag and washed at 60 ° C, and (b) to proceed with a high temperature steam anti-crease on the clothes after they have been tried on and for any item returned for exchange.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
